title.narrative: Denmark's core contribution to ISHR in 2020

description.narrative: The objective of the development cooperation is to improve the situation of the human rights defenders and safeguard the civil society space, and consequently amplify their impact and improve the international human rights situation overall, and specifically in relation to gender equality and sexual and reproductive health and rights. These are among the main strategic priorities as outlined in The World 2030.

organisation.narrative: Permanent Mission of Denmark to the UN in Geneva

mailing-address.narrative: Mission permanente du Danemark auprés de l'Office des Nations Unies à Genéve, 56 rue de Moillebeau, Case Postale 435

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: Support accountability of States for violations against women HRDs.
Concrete actions taken to support accountability of States for violations against women HRDs.

actual.value: - As part of the Women Human Rights Defenders Advocacy Week, ISHR worked with civil society partners to support a group of women defenders from El Salvador, Nicaragua, Colombia, Chile, Namibia, Kenya, Sudan, Indonesia, Philippines, Armenia and France to attend and address the Human Rights Council, as well as engage with UN human rights experts, on the role and protection of women defenders in conflict and post-conflict situations. - ISHR launched a new manual entitled ‘Our rights, our safety: Resources for WHRDs’ by and for women activists and human rights defenders. The manual builds on the experiences of women activists to help develop collective strategies and practices to keep women safer and stronger as they defend human rights. - ISHR worked with family members, civil society partners, UN experts and States to increase pressure on Saudi Arabia for the immediate and unconditional release of detained women human rights defenders, such as Loujain AlHathloul.

title.narrative: Support the development and strengthening of national HRD protection laws from a gender perspective
Concrete actions to support the development and strengthening of national HRD protection laws from a gender perspective

actual.value: - ISHR raised the attention of the UN Human Rights Council to the situation of LGBTI persons and those who defend their rights in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. - Yogyakarta Principles and the Yogyakarta Principles + 10 (the development of which were facilitated and led by ISHR and key civil society partners) have contributed to: o Enabling the registration of LGBTI organisations in Botswana o Successfully challenging the criminalisation of homosexuality in India o Enabling transgender persons to change their gender on their birth certificate while married in Australia o Supporting a bill before parliament on the protection of intersex persons in Argentina.
